event: Domestication of cats occurred in the Near East.
The earliest known indication for the taming of an African wildcat (F. lybica) was excavated in Shillourokambos, southern Cyprus.
The leopard cat (Prionailurus bengalensis) was tamed independently in China.
Cats were venerated in ancient Egypt.
The earliest known evidence for the occurrence of the domestic cat in Greece.
Domestic cats were familiar animals around settlements in Magna Graecia and Etruria.
The Egyptian domestic cat lineage arrived in a Baltic Sea port in northern Germany.
The word "cat" (Old English catt) was first used, possibly derived from Late Latin cattus.
The word "puss" (later extended to "pussy" and "pussycat") was introduced, possibly from Dutch poes or Low German puuskatte.
Carl Linnaeus proposed the scientific name Felis catus for a domestic cat.
Johann Christian Polycarp Erxleben proposed the scientific name Felis catus domesticus for a domestic cat.
Konstantin Satunin proposed the scientific name Felis daemon for a black cat from the Transcaucasus, later identified as a domestic cat.
The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature ruled that the domestic cat is a distinct species, Felis catus.
The domestic cat was considered a subspecies, F. silvestris catus, of the European wildcat (F. silvestris) following results of phylogenetic research.
Domestic cat was the second most popular pet in the United States, with 95.6 million cats owned.
Estimated population of 10.9 million pet cats in the United Kingdom.
Estimated 220 million owned and 480 million stray cats in the world.
